title: Can we generate electricity by a radio wave? - Quora

response.answer_text: You’re already doing it if you listen to a radio station with a crystal radio. But there is barely enough power there to drive the movements of the speaker cone or analogous device in your headphones. My guess is that it’s far more economically feasible to harvest the energy of the sun with photovoltaic cells than to use the movements of speaker coils to power nano-scale generators of electricity. If you were too close to a source of high voltage electricity, then you might do the Tesla trick and have lightbulbs in your house that would give off life without a visible source of power. What else would you need to make life perfect? A more useful, but inconstant, thing you could do would be to set up a tall antenna and insulate it well from the ground. Then run a wire from the antenna to a rechargeable battery, put in a voltage regulator, and pull electricity from passing clouds with a charge relative to earth. This is basically Ben Franklin’s experiment with the kite, the wire and a Leyden jar - Wikipedia. The only problem I can see with this is the same thing that made Ben’s experiment life-threatening. You might call down a lightning strike on your own person or house. I once was fooling around and made a “passing charge” detector. It moved the needle of a junked voltage meter by amplifying the charge detected from things like thunderstorm clouds in the distance. I doubt that the electric potential at the top of, e.g., the Eiffel Tower is ever zero for very long. It might be dangerous if people all over the earth started to discharge all the clouds passing overhead.

When I was working at a 50,000 Watt AM radio station, I lived about a block from the transmitter. I ran a wire from the peak of the roof to the basement, (single story house), and in the basement I built a crystal set, and was able to pick off 70 Volts from the crystal detector. (It was strong enough to drive a speaker loud enough to be heard all over the house!) (Sorry for the rough drawing)   OK, that 70 Volts wasn’t really GOOD for anything, but it was converting the signal from that transmitter about a mile away into enough electricity that it could “bite” you.

Radio waves can be used for transmitting energy over distance. It is not harnessing as one has to provide energy in the transmitting side. Very directional microwave antennas can transmit energy from solar panels in space into earth. What can’t be done is harnessing existing radio waves on the ground. There is too little energy in them to produce any useful amount and in the rare locations where the radio waves are strong it is dangerous to live.

People are looking at that with wifi to allow charging out of the air. But it will be very low power, so maybe useful for IoT type sensors, not your mobile phone. And it is very inefficient as an end-in-itself. Also, in a world one day saturated with IoT devices everywhere: to the extent that all these future devices power themselves off wifi, precisely to the same extent is the wifi signal attenuated.
In addition to previous answers: RFID passive tags collect energy from the EM field generated by a nearby transmitter. These tags can be used in motorways, stores, supermarkets, etc.

Do you mean by converting radio energy into electricity? Theoretically yes. Any energy can be transformed into any other form of energy but not all energy transformation is effective or worthwhile. Also, it may not be financially feasible. Also, we don’t always one energy form into another energy directly, sometimes they go through intermediate processes.
